sentences.zh: 秦之先，帝顓頊之苗裔孫曰女修。

translations.text: The ancestors of Qin were descendants of Emperor Zhuanxu, and a descendant named Nüxiu.

sentences.zh: 女修織，玄鳥隕卵，女修吞之，生子大業。

translations.text: While Nüxiu was weaving, a dark bird dropped an egg, which Nüxiu swallowed and gave birth to a son named Daye.

sentences.zh: 大業取少典之子，曰女華。

translations.text: Daye married a daughter of Shaodian, named Nühua.

sentences.zh: 女華生大費，與禹平水土。

translations.text: Nühua gave birth to Dafei, who helped Yu control the floods.

sentences.zh: 已成，帝錫玄圭。

translations.text: When the work was complete, the Emperor bestowed a dark jade tablet.

sentences.zh: 禹受曰：「非予能成，亦大費為輔。

translations.text: Yu received it and said: 'It was not I alone who accomplished this; Dafei assisted me.'

sentences.zh: 」帝舜曰：「咨爾費，贊禹功，其賜爾皁游。

translations.text: Emperor Shun said: 'Ah, you Fei, you assisted Yu's work, and I bestow upon you a black pennant.

sentences.zh: 爾後嗣將大出。

translations.text: Your descendants shall greatly flourish.'

sentences.zh: 」乃妻之姚姓之玉女。

translations.text: He then gave him a beautiful woman of the Yao surname as wife.

sentences.zh: 大費拜受，佐舜調馴鳥獸，鳥獸多馴服，是為柏翳。

translations.text: Dafei bowed and accepted, and assisted Shun in taming birds and beasts. Many birds and beasts became tame, and he was called Boyi.

sentences.zh: 舜賜姓嬴氏。

translations.text: Shun bestowed upon him the surname Ying.

The ancestors of Qin were descendants of Emperor Zhuanxu, and a descendant named Nüxiu. While Nüxiu was weaving, a dark bird dropped an egg, which Nüxiu swallowed and gave birth to a son named Daye. Daye married a daughter of Shaodian, named Nühua. Nühua gave birth to Dafei, who helped Yu control the floods. When the work was complete, the Emperor bestowed a dark jade tablet. Yu received it and said: 'It was not I alone who accomplished this; Dafei assisted me.' Emperor Shun said: 'Ah, you Fei, you assisted Yu's work, and I bestow upon you a black pennant. Your descendants shall greatly flourish.' He then gave him a beautiful woman of the Yao surname as wife. Dafei bowed and accepted, and assisted Shun in taming birds and beasts. Many birds and beasts became tame, and he was called Boyi. Shun bestowed upon him the surname Ying.

sentences.zh: 大費生子二人：一曰大廉，實鳥俗氏；

translations.text: Dafei had two sons: the first was Dalian, who founded the Niaoshu clan;

sentences.zh: 二曰若木，實費氏。

translations.text: the second was Ruomu, who founded the Fei clan.

sentences.zh: 其玄孫曰費昌，子孫或在中國，或在夷狄。

translations.text: His great-great-grandson was Feichang, whose descendants lived either in the Central States or among the barbarians.

sentences.zh: 費昌當夏桀之時，去夏歸商，為湯御，以敗桀於鳴條。

translations.text: Feichang, during the reign of Jie of Xia, left Xia and joined Shang, becoming Tang's charioteer and defeating Jie at Mingtiao.

sentences.zh: 大廉玄孫曰孟戲、中衍，鳥身人言。

translations.text: Dalian's great-great-grandson was named Mengxi and Zhongyan, who had bird-like bodies but spoke like humans.

sentences.zh: 帝太戊聞而卜之使御，吉，遂致使御而妻之。

translations.text: Emperor Taiwu heard of this and divined whether to employ him as a charioteer. The divination was auspicious, so he made him a charioteer and gave him a wife.

sentences.zh: 自太戊以下，中衍之後，遂世有功，以佐殷國，故嬴姓多顯，遂為諸侯。

translations.text: From Taiwu onward, the descendants of Zhongyan continued to achieve merit, assisting the Yin state, so the Ying surname became prominent and they became feudal lords.

Dafei had two sons: the first was Dalian, who founded the Niaoshu clan; the second was Ruomu, who founded the Fei clan. His great-great-grandson was Feichang, whose descendants lived either in the Central States or among the barbarians. Feichang, during the reign of Jie of Xia, left Xia and joined Shang, becoming Tang's charioteer and defeating Jie at Mingtiao. Dalian's great-great-grandson was named Mengxi and Zhongyan, who had bird-like bodies but spoke like humans. Emperor Taiwu heard of this and divined whether to employ him as a charioteer. The divination was auspicious, so he made him a charioteer and gave him a wife. From Taiwu onward, the descendants of Zhongyan continued to achieve merit, assisting the Yin state, so the Ying surname became prominent and they became feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 其玄孫曰中潏，在西戎，保西垂。

translations.text: His great-great-grandson was Zhongjue, who lived among the Western Rong and protected the western frontier.

sentences.zh: 生蜚廉。

translations.text: He fathered Feilian.

sentences.zh: 蜚廉生惡來。

translations.text: Feilian fathered Elai.

sentences.zh: 惡來有力，蜚廉善走，父子俱以材力事殷紂。

translations.text: Elai was strong, and Feilian was a swift runner; father and son both served Yin Zhou with their abilities.

sentences.zh: 周武王之伐紂，并殺惡來。

translations.text: When King Wu of Zhou attacked Zhou, he also killed Elai.

sentences.zh: 是時蜚廉為紂石北方，還，無所報，為壇霍太山而報，得石棺，銘曰「帝令處父不與殷亂，賜爾石棺以華氏」。

translations.text: At that time, Feilian was seeking stone for Zhou in the north. When he returned, having nowhere to report, he built an altar at Mount Huotai to make his report, and found a stone coffin with an inscription reading: 'The Emperor commands Chufu not to participate in Yin's chaos, and bestows upon you this stone coffin to honor the Hua clan.'

sentences.zh: 死，遂葬於霍太山。

translations.text: When he died, he was buried at Mount Huotai.

sentences.zh: 蜚廉復有子曰季勝。

translations.text: Feilian had another son named Jisheng.

sentences.zh: 季勝生孟增。

translations.text: Jisheng fathered Mengzeng.

sentences.zh: 孟增幸於周成王，是為宅皋狼。

translations.text: Mengzeng was favored by King Cheng of Zhou, and was called 'Dwelling at Gaolang.'

sentences.zh: 皋狼生衡父，衡父生造父。

translations.text: Gaolang fathered Hengfu, and Hengfu fathered Zaofu.

sentences.zh: 造父以善御幸於周繆王，得驥、溫驪、驊騮、騄耳之駟，西巡狩，樂而忘歸。

translations.text: Zaofu was favored by King Mu of Zhou for his excellent charioteering, and obtained the four horses Ji, Wenli, Hualiu, and Lu'er. They went on a western inspection tour, enjoying themselves so much they forgot to return.

sentences.zh: 徐偃王作亂，造父為繆王御，長驅歸周，一日千里以救亂。

translations.text: When Xu Yanwang rebelled, Zaofu served as King Mu's charioteer, driving swiftly back to Zhou, covering a thousand li in one day to suppress the rebellion.

sentences.zh: 繆王以趙城封造父，造父族由此為趙氏。

translations.text: King Mu enfeoffed Zaofu with the city of Zhao, and Zaofu's clan thereafter took the surname Zhao.

sentences.zh: 自蜚廉生季勝已下五世至造父，別居趙。

translations.text: From Feilian's son Jisheng down five generations to Zaofu, they separately resided in Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙衰其後也。

translations.text: Zhao Cui was his descendant.

sentences.zh: 惡來革者，蜚廉子也，蚤死。

translations.text: Elai Ge, son of Feilian, died young.

sentences.zh: 有子曰女防。

translations.text: He had a son named Nüfang.

sentences.zh: 女防生旁皋，旁皋生太幾，太幾生大駱，大駱生非子。

translations.text: Nüfang fathered Panggao, Panggao fathered Taiji, Taiji fathered Daluo, and Daluo fathered Feizi.

sentences.zh: 以造父之寵，皆蒙趙城，姓趙氏。

translations.text: Because of Zaofu's favor, they all received the city of Zhao and took the surname Zhao.

His great-great-grandson was Zhongjue, who lived among the Western Rong and protected the western frontier. He fathered Feilian. Feilian fathered Elai. Elai was strong, and Feilian was a swift runner; father and son both served Yin Zhou with their abilities. When King Wu of Zhou attacked Zhou, he also killed Elai. At that time, Feilian was seeking stone for Zhou in the north. When he returned, having nowhere to report, he built an altar at Mount Huotai to make his report, and found a stone coffin with an inscription reading: 'The Emperor commands Chufu not to participate in Yin's chaos, and bestows upon you this stone coffin to honor the Hua clan.' When he died, he was buried at Mount Huotai. Feilian had another son named Jisheng. Jisheng fathered Mengzeng. Mengzeng was favored by King Cheng of Zhou, and was called 'Dwelling at Gaolang.' Gaolang fathered Hengfu, and Hengfu fathered Zaofu. Zaofu was favored by King Mu of Zhou for his excellent charioteering, and obtained the four horses Ji, Wenli, Hualiu, and Lu'er. They went on a western inspection tour, enjoying themselves so much they forgot to return. When Xu Yanwang rebelled, Zaofu served as King Mu's charioteer, driving swiftly back to Zhou, covering a thousand li in one day to suppress the rebellion. King Mu enfeoffed Zaofu with the city of Zhao, and Zaofu's clan thereafter took the surname Zhao. From Feilian's son Jisheng down five generations to Zaofu, they separately resided in Zhao. Zhao Cui was his descendant. Elai Ge, son of Feilian, died young. He had a son named Nüfang. Nüfang fathered Panggao, Panggao fathered Taiji, Taiji fathered Daluo, and Daluo fathered Feizi. Because of Zaofu's favor, they all received the city of Zhao and took the surname Zhao.

sentences.zh: 非子居犬丘，好馬及畜，善養息之。

translations.text: Feizi lived at Quanqiu, where he loved horses and livestock and was skilled at raising them.

sentences.zh: 犬丘人言之周孝王，孝王召使主馬于汧渭之閒，馬大蕃息。

translations.text: The people of Quanqiu reported this to King Xiao of Zhou, who summoned him to manage horses between the Qian and Wei rivers, and the horses multiplied greatly.

sentences.zh: 孝王欲以為大駱適嗣。

translations.text: King Xiao wished to make him the legitimate heir of Daluo.

sentences.zh: 申侯之女為大駱妻，生子成為適。

translations.text: The daughter of the Marquis of Shen was Daluo's wife, and she bore a son Cheng as the legitimate heir.

sentences.zh: 申侯乃言孝王曰：「昔我先酈山之女，為戎胥軒妻，生中潏，以親故歸周，保西垂，西垂以其故和睦。

translations.text: The Marquis of Shen then said to King Xiao: 'Formerly, my ancestress, a woman of Mount Li, was wife to Rong Xuxuan and bore Zhongjue. Because of this kinship, they returned to Zhou and protected the western frontier, and the western frontier was peaceful because of this.

sentences.zh: 今我復與大駱妻，生適子成。

translations.text: Now I have again given a wife to Daluo, who bore the legitimate son Cheng.

sentences.zh: 申駱重婚，西戎皆服，所以為王。

translations.text: With the intermarriage of Shen and Luo, all the Western Rong submit; this is why you are king.

sentences.zh: 王其圖之。

translations.text: Your Majesty should consider this.'

sentences.zh: 」於是孝王曰：「昔伯翳為舜主畜，畜多息，故有土，賜姓嬴。

translations.text: King Xiao then said: 'Formerly, Boyi was Shun's master of livestock, and the livestock multiplied greatly, so he received land and was granted the surname Ying.

sentences.zh: 今其後世亦為朕息馬，朕其分土為附庸。

translations.text: Now his descendants also raise horses for me, so I shall grant them territory as a dependent state.'

sentences.zh: 」邑之秦，使復續嬴氏祀，號曰秦嬴。

translations.text: He established them at Qin, allowing them to continue the sacrifices of the Ying clan, and called them Qin Ying.

sentences.zh: 亦不廢申侯之女子為駱適者，以和西戎。

translations.text: He also did not abolish the son of the Marquis of Shen's daughter as Luo's legitimate heir, in order to maintain peace with the Western Rong.

Feizi lived at Quanqiu, where he loved horses and livestock and was skilled at raising them. The people of Quanqiu reported this to King Xiao of Zhou, who summoned him to manage horses between the Qian and Wei rivers, and the horses multiplied greatly. King Xiao wished to make him the legitimate heir of Daluo. The daughter of the Marquis of Shen was Daluo's wife, and she bore a son Cheng as the legitimate heir. The Marquis of Shen then said to King Xiao: 'Formerly, my ancestress, a woman of Mount Li, was wife to Rong Xuxuan and bore Zhongjue. Because of this kinship, they returned to Zhou and protected the western frontier, and the western frontier was peaceful because of this. Now I have again given a wife to Daluo, who bore the legitimate son Cheng. With the intermarriage of Shen and Luo, all the Western Rong submit; this is why you are king. Your Majesty should consider this.' King Xiao then said: 'Formerly, Boyi was Shun's master of livestock, and the livestock multiplied greatly, so he received land and was granted the surname Ying. Now his descendants also raise horses for me, so I shall grant them territory as a dependent state.' He established them at Qin, allowing them to continue the sacrifices of the Ying clan, and called them Qin Ying. He also did not abolish the son of the Marquis of Shen's daughter as Luo's legitimate heir, in order to maintain peace with the Western Rong.

sentences.zh: 秦嬴生秦侯。

translations.text: Qin Ying fathered Duke of Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦侯立十年，卒。

translations.text: The Duke of Qin reigned for ten years and died.

sentences.zh: 生公伯。

translations.text: He fathered Gongbo.

sentences.zh: 公伯立三年，卒。

translations.text: Gongbo reigned for three years and died.

sentences.zh: 生秦仲。

translations.text: He fathered Qin Zhong.
Qin Ying fathered Duke of Qin. The Duke of Qin reigned for ten years and died. He fathered Gongbo. Gongbo reigned for three years and died. He fathered Qin Zhong.

sentences.zh: 秦仲立三年，周厲王無道，諸侯或叛之。

translations.text: In the third year of Qin Zhong's reign, King Li of Zhou was tyrannical, and some feudal lords rebelled against him.

sentences.zh: 西戎反王室，滅犬丘大駱之族。

translations.text: The Western Rong rebelled against the royal house and exterminated the Daluo clan at Quanqiu.

sentences.zh: 周宣王即位，乃以秦仲為大夫，誅西戎。

translations.text: When King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne, he made Qin Zhong a grand master and ordered him to punish the Western Rong.

sentences.zh: 西戎殺秦仲。

translations.text: The Western Rong killed Qin Zhong.

sentences.zh: 秦仲立二十三年，死於戎。

translations.text: Qin Zhong had reigned for twenty-three years when he died at the hands of the Rong.

sentences.zh: 有子五人，其長者曰莊公。

translations.text: He had five sons, the eldest of whom was Duke Zhuang.

sentences.zh: 周宣王乃召莊公昆弟五人，與兵七千人，使伐西戎，破之。

translations.text: King Xuan of Zhou summoned Duke Zhuang and his four brothers, gave them seven thousand soldiers, and ordered them to attack the Western Rong. They defeated them.

sentences.zh: 於是復予秦仲後，及其先大駱地犬丘并有之，為西垂大夫。

translations.text: Thereupon, he restored to Qin Zhong's descendants the lands of their ancestor Daluo at Quanqiu, and made them Grand Masters of the Western Frontier.

In the third year of Qin Zhong's reign, King Li of Zhou was tyrannical, and some feudal lords rebelled against him. The Western Rong rebelled against the royal house and exterminated the Daluo clan at Quanqiu. When King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne, he made Qin Zhong a grand master and ordered him to punish the Western Rong. The Western Rong killed Qin Zhong. Qin Zhong had reigned for twenty-three years when he died at the hands of the Rong. He had five sons, the eldest of whom was Duke Zhuang. King Xuan of Zhou summoned Duke Zhuang and his four brothers, gave them seven thousand soldiers, and ordered them to attack the Western Rong. They defeated them. Thereupon, he restored to Qin Zhong's descendants the lands of their ancestor Daluo at Quanqiu, and made them Grand Masters of the Western Frontier.

sentences.zh: 莊公居其故西犬丘，生子三人，其長男世父。

translations.text: Duke Zhuang resided at the former Western Quanqiu and had three sons, the eldest being Shifu.

sentences.zh: 世父曰：「戎殺我大父仲，我非殺戎王則不敢入邑。

translations.text: Shifu said: 'The Rong killed my grandfather Zhong. Unless I kill the Rong king, I will not dare enter the town.'

sentences.zh: 」遂將擊戎，讓其弟襄公。

translations.text: He then went to attack the Rong, yielding the succession to his younger brother Duke Xiang.

sentences.zh: 襄公為太子。

translations.text: Duke Xiang became heir apparent.

sentences.zh: 莊公立四十四年，卒，太子襄公代立。

translations.text: Duke Zhuang reigned for forty-four years and died. His heir, Duke Xiang, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 襄公元年，以女弟繆嬴為豐王妻。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, he gave his younger sister Mu Ying in marriage to the king of Feng.

sentences.zh: 襄公二年，戎圍犬丘，（世父）世父擊之，為戎人所虜。

translations.text: In the second year of Duke Xiang's reign, the Rong besieged Quanqiu. Shifu attacked them but was captured by the Rong.

sentences.zh: 歲餘，復歸世父。

translations.text: After more than a year, Shifu was returned.

sentences.zh: 七年春，周幽王用褒姒廢太子，立褒姒子為適，數欺諸侯，諸侯叛之。

translations.text: In the seventh year, in spring, King You of Zhou used Baosi to depose the heir apparent and made Baosi's son the legitimate heir. He repeatedly deceived the feudal lords, and the feudal lords rebelled against him.

sentences.zh: 西戎犬戎與申侯伐周，殺幽王酈山下。

translations.text: The Western Rong and the Quanrong, together with the Marquis of Shen, attacked Zhou and killed King You below Mount Li.

sentences.zh: 而秦襄公將兵救周，戰甚力，有功。

translations.text: Duke Xiang of Qin led troops to rescue Zhou, fought valiantly, and achieved merit.

sentences.zh: 周避犬戎難，東徙雒邑，襄公以兵送周平王。

translations.text: Zhou fled from the Quanrong threat and moved east to Luoyi. Duke Xiang escorted King Ping of Zhou with his troops.

sentences.zh: 平王封襄公為諸侯，賜之岐以西之地。

translations.text: King Ping enfeoffed Duke Xiang as a feudal lord and granted him the lands west of Qi.

sentences.zh: 曰：「戎無道，侵奪我岐、豐之地，秦能攻逐戎，即有其地。

translations.text: He said: 'The Rong are lawless and have invaded and seized our lands of Qi and Feng. If Qin can attack and drive out the Rong, the land shall be yours.'

sentences.zh: 」與誓，封爵之。

translations.text: He made a covenant with him and enfeoffed him with noble rank.

sentences.zh: 襄公於是始國，與諸侯通使聘享之禮，乃用騮駒、黃牛、羝羊各三，祠上帝西畤。

translations.text: Thus Duke Xiang first established a state. He exchanged diplomatic courtesies with the other feudal lords, and offered sacrifices to the Supreme Deity at the Western Altar using three each of bay colts, yellow oxen, and rams.

sentences.zh: 十二年，伐戎而至岐，卒。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, he attacked the Rong and reached Qi, where he died.

sentences.zh: 生文公。

translations.text: He fathered Duke Wen.

Duke Zhuang resided at the former Western Quanqiu and had three sons, the eldest being Shifu. Shifu said: 'The Rong killed my grandfather Zhong. Unless I kill the Rong king, I will not dare enter the town.' He then went to attack the Rong, yielding the succession to his younger brother Duke Xiang. Duke Xiang became heir apparent. Duke Zhuang reigned for forty-four years and died. His heir, Duke Xiang, succeeded him. In the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, he gave his younger sister Mu Ying in marriage to the king of Feng. In the second year of Duke Xiang's reign, the Rong besieged Quanqiu. Shifu attacked them but was captured by the Rong. After more than a year, Shifu was returned. In the seventh year, in spring, King You of Zhou used Baosi to depose the heir apparent and made Baosi's son the legitimate heir. He repeatedly deceived the feudal lords, and the feudal lords rebelled against him. The Western Rong and the Quanrong, together with the Marquis of Shen, attacked Zhou and killed King You below Mount Li. Duke Xiang of Qin led troops to rescue Zhou, fought valiantly, and achieved merit. Zhou fled from the Quanrong threat and moved east to Luoyi. Duke Xiang escorted King Ping of Zhou with his troops. King Ping enfeoffed Duke Xiang as a feudal lord and granted him the lands west of Qi. He said: 'The Rong are lawless and have invaded and seized our lands of Qi and Feng. If Qin can attack and drive out the Rong, the land shall be yours.' He made a covenant with him and enfeoffed him with noble rank. Thus Duke Xiang first established a state. He exchanged diplomatic courtesies with the other feudal lords, and offered sacrifices to the Supreme Deity at the Western Altar using three each of bay colts, yellow oxen, and rams. In the twelfth year, he attacked the Rong and reached Qi, where he died. He fathered Duke Wen.

sentences.zh: 文公元年，居西垂宮。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke Wen's reign, he resided at the Western Frontier Palace.

sentences.zh: 三年，文公以兵七百人東獵。

translations.text: In the third year, Duke Wen led seven hundred soldiers on an eastern hunting expedition.

sentences.zh: 四年，至汧渭之會。

translations.text: In the fourth year, he reached the confluence of the Qian and Wei rivers.

sentences.zh: 曰：「昔周邑我先秦嬴於此，後卒獲為諸侯。

translations.text: He said: 'Formerly, Zhou established our ancestor Qin Ying here, and eventually he became a feudal lord.'

sentences.zh: 」乃卜居之，占曰吉，即營邑之。

translations.text: He then divined about settling there, and the omen was auspicious, so he built a town there.

sentences.zh: 十年，初為鄜畤，用三牢。

translations.text: In the tenth year, he first established the Fu Altar and offered three sets of sacrificial animals.

sentences.zh: 十三年，初有史以紀事，民多化者。

translations.text: In the thirteenth year, scribes were first employed to record events, and many people became civilized.

sentences.zh: 十六年，文公以兵伐戎，戎敗走。

translations.text: In the sixteenth year, Duke Wen led troops to attack the Rong, and the Rong were defeated and fled.

sentences.zh: 於是文公遂收周餘民有之，地至岐，岐以東獻之周。

translations.text: Duke Wen then gathered the remaining people of Zhou and possessed them, extending his territory to Qi. The lands east of Qi he offered to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 十九年，得陳寶。

translations.text: In the nineteenth year, he obtained the Chen Treasure.

sentences.zh: 二十年，法初有三族之罪。

translations.text: In the twentieth year, laws first included punishment extending to three generations of kin.

sentences.zh: 二十七年，伐南山大梓，豐大特。

translations.text: In the twenty-seventh year, he cut down the great catalpa on the Southern Mountain, and encountered a great bull.

sentences.zh: 四十八年，文公太子卒，賜謚為竫公。

translations.text: In the forty-eighth year, Duke Wen's heir apparent died and was posthumously titled Duke Jing.

sentences.zh: 竫公之長子為太子，是文公孫也。

translations.text: Duke Jing's eldest son became heir apparent; he was Duke Wen's grandson.

sentences.zh: 五十年，文公卒，葬西山。

translations.text: In the fiftieth year, Duke Wen died and was buried at the Western Mountain.

sentences.zh: 竫公子立，是為寧公。

translations.text: Duke Jing's son ascended the throne; this was Duke Ning.

In the first year of Duke Wen's reign, he resided at the Western Frontier Palace. In the third year, Duke Wen led seven hundred soldiers on an eastern hunting expedition. In the fourth year, he reached the confluence of the Qian and Wei rivers. He said: 'Formerly, Zhou established our ancestor Qin Ying here, and eventually he became a feudal lord.' He then divined about settling there, and the omen was auspicious, so he built a town there. In the tenth year, he first established the Fu Altar and offered three sets of sacrificial animals. In the thirteenth year, scribes were first employed to record events, and many people became civilized. In the sixteenth year, Duke Wen led troops to attack the Rong, and the Rong were defeated and fled. Duke Wen then gathered the remaining people of Zhou and possessed them, extending his territory to Qi. The lands east of Qi he offered to Zhou. In the nineteenth year, he obtained the Chen Treasure. In the twentieth year, laws first included punishment extending to three generations of kin. In the twenty-seventh year, he cut down the great catalpa on the Southern Mountain, and encountered a great bull. In the forty-eighth year, Duke Wen's heir apparent died and was posthumously titled Duke Jing. Duke Jing's eldest son became heir apparent; he was Duke Wen's grandson. In the fiftieth year, Duke Wen died and was buried at the Western Mountain. Duke Jing's son ascended the throne; this was Duke Ning.

sentences.zh: 寧公二年，公徙居平陽。

translations.text: In the second year of Duke Ning's reign, the duke moved his residence to Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 遣兵伐蕩社。

translations.text: He sent troops to attack Dangshe.

sentences.zh: 三年，與亳戰，亳王奔戎，遂滅蕩社。

translations.text: In the third year, he fought with Bo. The king of Bo fled to the Rong, and Dangshe was subsequently destroyed.

sentences.zh: 四年，魯公子翬弒其君隱公。

translations.text: In the fourth year, the Lu prince Hui assassinated his ruler Duke Yin.

sentences.zh: 十二年，伐蕩氏，取之。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, he attacked the Dang clan and captured them.

sentences.zh: 寧公生十歲立，立十二年卒，葬西山。

translations.text: Duke Ning was ten years old when he ascended the throne, and reigned for twelve years before dying. He was buried at the Western Mountain.

sentences.zh: 生子三人，長男武公為太子。

translations.text: He had three sons; the eldest, Duke Wu, was heir apparent.

sentences.zh: 武公弟德公，同母魯姬子。

translations.text: Duke Wu's younger brother was Duke De, born of the same mother, the daughter of Lu Ji.

sentences.zh: 生出子。

translations.text: She gave birth to Chuzi.

sentences.zh: 寧公卒，大庶長弗忌、威壘、三父廢太子而立出子為君。

translations.text: When Duke Ning died, the Grand Secretary Fuji, Weilei, and Sanfu deposed the heir apparent and established Chuzi as ruler.

sentences.zh: 出子六年，三父等復共令人賊殺出子。

translations.text: In the sixth year of Chuzi's reign, Sanfu and the others again conspired to have someone assassinate Chuzi.

sentences.zh: 出子生五歲立，立六年卒。

translations.text: Chuzi was five years old when he was established, and ruled for six years before dying.

sentences.zh: 三父等乃復立故太子武公。

translations.text: Sanfu and the others then reinstated the former heir apparent, Duke Wu.

In the second year of Duke Ning's reign, the duke moved his residence to Pingyang. He sent troops to attack Dangshe. In the third year, he fought with Bo. The king of Bo fled to the Rong, and Dangshe was subsequently destroyed. In the fourth year, the Lu prince Hui assassinated his ruler Duke Yin. In the twelfth year, he attacked the Dang clan and captured them. Duke Ning was ten years old when he ascended the throne, and reigned for twelve years before dying. He was buried at the Western Mountain. He had three sons; the eldest, Duke Wu, was heir apparent. Duke Wu's younger brother was Duke De, born of the same mother, the daughter of Lu Ji. She gave birth to Chuzi. When Duke Ning died, the Grand Secretary Fuji, Weilei, and Sanfu deposed the heir apparent and established Chuzi as ruler. In the sixth year of Chuzi's reign, Sanfu and the others again conspired to have someone assassinate Chuzi. Chuzi was five years old when he was established, and ruled for six years before dying. Sanfu and the others then reinstated the former heir apparent, Duke Wu.

sentences.zh: 武公元年，伐彭戲氏，至于華山下，居平陽封宮。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke Wu's reign, he attacked the Pengxi clan, reaching the foot of Mount Hua, and resided at the Feng Palace in Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 三年，誅三父等而夷三族，以其殺出子也。

translations.text: In the third year, he executed Sanfu and the others and exterminated their three clans, because they had killed Chuzi.

sentences.zh: 鄭高渠瞇殺其君昭公。

translations.text: Gao Qumi of Zheng killed his ruler Duke Zhao.

sentences.zh: 十年，伐邽、冀戎，初縣之。

translations.text: In the tenth year, he attacked the Gui and Ji Rong, and first established them as counties.

sentences.zh: 十一年，初縣杜、鄭。

translations.text: In the eleventh year, he first established Du and Zheng as counties.

sentences.zh: 滅小虢。

translations.text: He destroyed Little Guo.

In the first year of Duke Wu's reign, he attacked the Pengxi clan, reaching the foot of Mount Hua, and resided at the Feng Palace in Pingyang. In the third year, he executed Sanfu and the others and exterminated their three clans, because they had killed Chuzi. Gao Qumi of Zheng killed his ruler Duke Zhao. In the tenth year, he attacked the Gui and Ji Rong, and first established them as counties. In the eleventh year, he first established Du and Zheng as counties. He destroyed Little Guo.

sentences.zh: 十三年，齊人管至父、連稱等殺其君襄公而立公孫無知。

translations.text: In the thirteenth year, Guan Zhifu and Lian Cheng of Qi killed their ruler Duke Xiang and established Gongsun Wuzhi.

sentences.zh: 晉滅霍、魏、耿。

translations.text: Jin destroyed Huo, Wei, and Geng.

sentences.zh: 齊雍廩殺無知、管至父等而立齊桓公。

translations.text: Yong Lin of Qi killed Wuzhi and Guan Zhifu and others, and established Duke Huan of Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊、晉為彊國。

translations.text: Qi and Jin became powerful states.

In the thirteenth year, Guan Zhifu and Lian Cheng of Qi killed their ruler Duke Xiang and established Gongsun Wuzhi. Jin destroyed Huo, Wei, and Geng. Yong Lin of Qi killed Wuzhi and Guan Zhifu and others, and established Duke Huan of Qi. Qi and Jin became powerful states.

sentences.zh: 十九年，晉曲沃始為晉侯。

translations.text: In the nineteenth year, Quwo of Jin first became the Marquis of Jin.

sentences.zh: 齊桓公伯於鄄。

translations.text: Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon at Juan.
In the nineteenth year, Quwo of Jin first became the Marquis of Jin. Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon at Juan.

sentences.zh: 二十年，武公卒，葬雍平陽。

translations.text: In the twentieth year, Duke Wu died and was buried at Yong Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 初以人從死，從死者六十六人。

translations.text: For the first time, human sacrifices accompanied the burial; sixty-six people were sacrificed.

sentences.zh: 有子一人，名曰白，白不立，封平陽。

translations.text: He had one son named Bai. Bai was not established as ruler, but was enfeoffed at Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 立其弟德公。

translations.text: His younger brother Duke De was established.

In the twentieth year, Duke Wu died and was buried at Yong Pingyang. For the first time, human sacrifices accompanied the burial; sixty-six people were sacrificed. He had one son named Bai. Bai was not established as ruler, but was enfeoffed at Pingyang. His younger brother Duke De was established.

sentences.zh: 德公元年，初居雍城大鄭宮。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke De's reign, he first resided at the Dazheng Palace in the city of Yong.

sentences.zh: 以犧三百牢祠鄜畤。

translations.text: He offered three hundred sets of sacrificial animals at the Fu Altar.

sentences.zh: 卜居雍。

translations.text: He divined about residing at Yong.

sentences.zh: 後子孫飲馬於河。

translations.text: His descendants would water their horses at the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 梁伯、芮伯來朝。

translations.text: The Earl of Liang and the Earl of Rui came to pay court.

sentences.zh: 二年，初伏，以狗御蠱。

translations.text: In the second year, the first Dog Days sacrifice was instituted, using dogs to ward off pestilence.

sentences.zh: 德公生三十三歲而立，立二年卒。

translations.text: Duke De was thirty-three years old when he ascended the throne, and reigned for two years before dying.

sentences.zh: 生子三人：長子宣公，中子成公，少子穆公。

translations.text: He had three sons: the eldest was Duke Xuan, the second was Duke Cheng, and the youngest was Duke Mu.

sentences.zh: 長子宣公立。

translations.text: The eldest son Duke Xuan was established.

In the first year of Duke De's reign, he first resided at the Dazheng Palace in the city of Yong. He offered three hundred sets of sacrificial animals at the Fu Altar. He divined about residing at Yong. His descendants would water their horses at the Yellow River. The Earl of Liang and the Earl of Rui came to pay court. In the second year, the first Dog Days sacrifice was instituted, using dogs to ward off pestilence. Duke De was thirty-three years old when he ascended the throne, and reigned for two years before dying. He had three sons: the eldest was Duke Xuan, the second was Duke Cheng, and the youngest was Duke Mu. The eldest son Duke Xuan was established.

sentences.zh: 宣公元年，衛、燕伐周，出惠王，立王子穨。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke Xuan's reign, Wei and Yan attacked Zhou, expelled King Hui, and established Prince Tui.

sentences.zh: 三年，鄭伯、虢叔殺子穨而入惠王。

translations.text: In the third year, the Earl of Zheng and Uncle of Guo killed Prince Tui and restored King Hui.

sentences.zh: 四年，作密畤。

translations.text: In the fourth year, he established the Mi Altar.

sentences.zh: 與晉戰河陽，勝之。

translations.text: He fought with Jin at Heyang and defeated them.

sentences.zh: 十二年，宣公卒。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, Duke Xuan died.

sentences.zh: 生子九人，莫立，立其弟成公。

translations.text: He had nine sons, but none was established; his younger brother Duke Cheng was established.

In the first year of Duke Xuan's reign, Wei and Yan attacked Zhou, expelled King Hui, and established Prince Tui. In the third year, the Earl of Zheng and Uncle of Guo killed Prince Tui and restored King Hui. In the fourth year, he established the Mi Altar. He fought with Jin at Heyang and defeated them. In the twelfth year, Duke Xuan died. He had nine sons, but none was established; his younger brother Duke Cheng was established.

sentences.zh: 成公元年，梁伯、芮伯來朝。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke Cheng's reign, the Earl of Liang and the Earl of Rui came to pay court.

sentences.zh: 齊桓公伐山戎，次于孤竹。

translations.text: Duke Huan of Qi attacked the Shanrong and encamped at Guzhu.
In the first year of Duke Cheng's reign, the Earl of Liang and the Earl of Rui came to pay court. Duke Huan of Qi attacked the Shanrong and encamped at Guzhu.

sentences.zh: 成公立四年卒。

translations.text: Duke Cheng reigned for four years and died.

sentences.zh: 子七人，莫立，立其弟繆公。

translations.text: He had seven sons, but none was established; his younger brother Duke Mu was established.
Duke Cheng reigned for four years and died. He had seven sons, but none was established; his younger brother Duke Mu was established.

sentences.zh: 繆公任好元年，自將伐茅津，勝之。

translations.text: In the first year of Duke Mu Renhao's reign, he personally led an attack on Maojin and defeated it.

sentences.zh: 四年，迎婦於晉，晉太子申生姊也。

translations.text: In the fourth year, he received a bride from Jin, who was the elder sister of Jin's heir apparent Shensheng.

sentences.zh: 其歲，齊桓公伐楚，至邵陵。

translations.text: That year, Duke Huan of Qi attacked Chu and reached Shaoling.

In the first year of Duke Mu Renhao's reign, he personally led an attack on Maojin and defeated it. In the fourth year, he received a bride from Jin, who was the elder sister of Jin's heir apparent Shensheng. That year, Duke Huan of Qi attacked Chu and reached Shaoling.

sentences.zh: 五年，晉獻公滅虞、虢，虜虞君與其大夫百里傒，以璧馬賂於虞故也。

translations.text: In the fifth year, Duke Xian of Jin destroyed Yu and Guo, and captured the ruler of Yu along with his minister Baili Xi, because they had bribed Yu with jade and horses.

sentences.zh: 既虜百里傒，以為秦繆公夫人媵於秦。

translations.text: After capturing Baili Xi, he was sent to Qin as an attendant for Duke Mu's wife.

sentences.zh: 百里傒亡秦走宛，楚鄙人執之。

translations.text: Baili Xi fled from Qin to Wan, where he was seized by a man from the Chu border region.

sentences.zh: 繆公聞百里傒賢，欲重贖之，恐楚人不與，乃使人謂楚曰：「吾媵臣百里傒在焉，請以五羖羊皮贖之。

translations.text: Duke Mu heard that Baili Xi was worthy and wanted to ransom him at a high price, but feared Chu would not release him. So he sent someone to say to Chu: 'My attendant Baili Xi is there; please let me ransom him for five ram skins.'

sentences.zh: 楚人遂許與之。

translations.text: The people of Chu agreed to give him up.

sentences.zh: 當是時，百里傒年已七十餘。

translations.text: At that time, Baili Xi was already over seventy years old.

sentences.zh: 繆公釋其囚，與語國事。

translations.text: Duke Mu released him from captivity and discussed state affairs with him.

sentences.zh: 謝曰：「臣亡國之臣，何足問！

translations.text: Baili Xi declined, saying: 'I am a minister of a fallen state; what is there to ask me?'

sentences.zh: 」繆公曰：「虞君不用子，故亡，非子罪也。

translations.text: Duke Mu said: 'The ruler of Yu did not employ you, and so perished. It was not your fault.'

sentences.zh: 」固問，語三日，繆公大說，授之國政，號曰五羖大夫。

translations.text: He persisted in questioning him, and they talked for three days. Duke Mu was greatly pleased, entrusted him with the administration of the state, and called him 'Grand Master of the Five Ram Skins.'

sentences.zh: 百里傒讓曰：「臣不及臣友蹇叔，蹇叔賢而世莫知。

translations.text: Baili Xi declined, saying: 'I am not as good as my friend Jian Shu. Jian Shu is worthy, but the world does not know him.

sentences.zh: 臣常游困於齊而乞食铚人，蹇叔收臣。

translations.text: I once wandered in poverty in Qi and begged for food in Zhi. Jian Shu took me in.

sentences.zh: 臣因而欲事齊君無知，蹇叔止臣，臣得脫齊難，遂之周。

translations.text: Because of this, I wanted to serve the ruler of Qi, Wuzhi, but Jian Shu stopped me, and I escaped the troubles in Qi and went to Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周王子穨好牛，臣以養牛干之。

translations.text: The Zhou prince Tui loved cattle, and I approached him through raising cattle.

sentences.zh: 及穨欲用臣，蹇叔止臣，臣去，得不誅。

translations.text: When Tui was about to employ me, Jian Shu stopped me; I left and avoided being executed.

sentences.zh: 事虞君，蹇叔止臣。

translations.text: When I served the ruler of Yu, Jian Shu stopped me.

sentences.zh: 臣知虞君不用臣，臣誠私利祿爵，且留。

translations.text: I knew the ruler of Yu would not employ me, but I was truly covetous of the salary and rank, so I stayed.

sentences.zh: 再用其言，得脫，一不用，及虞君難：是以知其賢。

translations.text: Twice I followed his advice and escaped; once I did not follow it, and I was caught up in Yu's troubles. This is how I know he is worthy.'

sentences.zh: 」於是繆公使人厚幣迎蹇叔，以為上大夫。

translations.text: Duke Mu then sent someone with generous gifts to invite Jian Shu, and made him a Senior Grand Master.

In the fifth year, Duke Xian of Jin destroyed Yu and Guo, and captured the ruler of Yu along with his minister Baili Xi, because they had bribed Yu with jade and horses. After capturing Baili Xi, he was sent to Qin as an attendant for Duke Mu's wife. Baili Xi fled from Qin to Wan, where he was seized by a man from the Chu border region. Duke Mu heard that Baili Xi was worthy and wanted to ransom him at a high price, but feared Chu would not release him. So he sent someone to say to Chu: 'My attendant Baili Xi is there; please let me ransom him for five ram skins.' The people of Chu agreed to give him up. At that time, Baili Xi was already over seventy years old. Duke Mu released him from captivity and discussed state affairs with him. Baili Xi declined, saying: 'I am a minister of a fallen state; what is there to ask me?' Duke Mu said: 'The ruler of Yu did not employ you, and so perished. It was not your fault.' He persisted in questioning him, and they talked for three days. Duke Mu was greatly pleased, entrusted him with the administration of the state, and called him 'Grand Master of the Five Ram Skins.' Baili Xi declined, saying: 'I am not as good as my friend Jian Shu. Jian Shu is worthy, but the world does not know him. I once wandered in poverty in Qi and begged for food in Zhi. Jian Shu took me in. Because of this, I wanted to serve the ruler of Qi, Wuzhi, but Jian Shu stopped me, and I escaped the troubles in Qi and went to Zhou. The Zhou prince Tui loved cattle, and I approached him through raising cattle. When Tui was about to employ me, Jian Shu stopped me; I left and avoided being executed. When I served the ruler of Yu, Jian Shu stopped me. I knew the ruler of Yu would not employ me, but I was truly covetous of the salary and rank, so I stayed. Twice I followed his advice and escaped; once I did not follow it, and I was caught up in Yu's troubles. This is how I know he is worthy.' Duke Mu then sent someone with generous gifts to invite Jian Shu, and made him a Senior Grand Master.

sentences.zh: 秋，繆公自將伐晉，戰於河曲。

translations.text: In the autumn, Duke Mu personally led an attack on Jin and fought at Hequ.

sentences.zh: 晉驪姬作亂，太子申生死新城，重耳、夷吾出奔。

translations.text: Li Ji of Jin caused turmoil. The heir apparent Shensheng died at Xincheng, and Chong'er and Yiwu fled.
In the autumn, Duke Mu personally led an attack on Jin and fought at Hequ. Li Ji of Jin caused turmoil. The heir apparent Shensheng died at Xincheng, and Chong'er and Yiwu fled.

sentences.zh: 九年，齊桓公會諸侯於葵丘。

translations.text: In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi held a meeting of the feudal lords at Kuiqiu.
In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi held a meeting of the feudal lords at Kuiqiu.

sentences.zh: 晉獻公卒。

translations.text: Duke Xian of Jin died.

sentences.zh: 立驪姬子奚齊，其臣里克殺奚齊。

translations.text: Li Ji's son Xiqi was established, but the minister Li Ke killed Xiqi.

sentences.zh: 荀息立卓子，克又殺卓子及荀息。

translations.text: Xun Xi established Zhuozi, but Li Ke again killed Zhuozi and Xun Xi.

sentences.zh: 夷吾使人請秦，求入晉。

translations.text: Yiwu sent someone to request Qin's help to enter Jin.

sentences.zh: 於是繆公許之，使百里傒將兵送夷吾。

translations.text: Duke Mu agreed and sent Baili Xi to lead troops escorting Yiwu.

sentences.zh: 夷吾謂曰：「誠得立，請割晉之河西八城與秦。

translations.text: Yiwu said: 'If I am truly established, I will cede eight cities west of the Jin river to Qin.'

sentences.zh: 」及至，已立，而使丕鄭謝秦，背約不與河西城，而殺裏克。

translations.text: When he arrived and was established, he sent Pi Zheng to apologize to Qin, reneged on the agreement and did not give the cities west of the river, and killed Li Ke.

sentences.zh: 丕鄭聞之，恐，因與繆公謀曰：「晉人不欲夷吾，實欲重耳。

translations.text: When Pi Zheng heard this, he was afraid, and so conspired with Duke Mu, saying: 'The people of Jin do not want Yiwu; they really want Chong'er.

sentences.zh: 今背秦約而殺裏克，皆呂甥、郤芮之計也。

translations.text: Now that he has broken the agreement with Qin and killed Li Ke, this is all the plan of Lü Sheng and Xi Rui.

sentences.zh: 願君以利急召呂、郤，呂、郤至，則更入重耳便。

translations.text: I hope you will urgently summon Lü and Xi with promises of gain; when they come, it will be convenient to install Chong'er instead.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公許之，使人與丕鄭歸，召呂、郤。

translations.text: Duke Mu agreed, and sent someone with Pi Zheng to return and summon Lü and Xi.

sentences.zh: 呂、郤等疑丕鄭有閒，乃言夷吾殺丕鄭。

translations.text: Lü, Xi, and the others suspected that Pi Zheng was plotting against them, so they told Yiwu to kill Pi Zheng.

sentences.zh: 丕鄭子丕豹奔秦，說繆公曰：「晉君無道，百姓不親，可伐也。

translations.text: Pi Zheng's son Pi Bao fled to Qin and persuaded Duke Mu, saying: 'The ruler of Jin is unprincipled and the people are not attached to him; he can be attacked.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公曰：「百姓茍不便，何故能誅其大臣？

translations.text: Duke Mu said: 'If the people are truly dissatisfied, how was he able to execute his minister?

sentences.zh: 能誅其大臣，此其調也。

translations.text: That he could execute his minister shows he has control.'

sentences.zh: 」不聽，而陰用豹。

translations.text: He did not listen, but secretly employed Pi Bao.

Duke Xian of Jin died. Li Ji's son Xiqi was established, but the minister Li Ke killed Xiqi. Xun Xi established Zhuozi, but Li Ke again killed Zhuozi and Xun Xi. Yiwu sent someone to request Qin's help to enter Jin. Duke Mu agreed and sent Baili Xi to lead troops escorting Yiwu. Yiwu said: 'If I am truly established, I will cede eight cities west of the Jin river to Qin.' When he arrived and was established, he sent Pi Zheng to apologize to Qin, reneged on the agreement and did not give the cities west of the river, and killed Li Ke. When Pi Zheng heard this, he was afraid, and so conspired with Duke Mu, saying: 'The people of Jin do not want Yiwu; they really want Chong'er. Now that he has broken the agreement with Qin and killed Li Ke, this is all the plan of Lü Sheng and Xi Rui. I hope you will urgently summon Lü and Xi with promises of gain; when they come, it will be convenient to install Chong'er instead.' Duke Mu agreed, and sent someone with Pi Zheng to return and summon Lü and Xi. Lü, Xi, and the others suspected that Pi Zheng was plotting against them, so they told Yiwu to kill Pi Zheng. Pi Zheng's son Pi Bao fled to Qin and persuaded Duke Mu, saying: 'The ruler of Jin is unprincipled and the people are not attached to him; he can be attacked.' Duke Mu said: 'If the people are truly dissatisfied, how was he able to execute his minister? That he could execute his minister shows he has control.' He did not listen, but secretly employed Pi Bao.

sentences.zh: 十二年，齊管仲、隰朋死。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, Guan Zhong and Xi Peng of Qi died.
In the twelfth year, Guan Zhong and Xi Peng of Qi died.

sentences.zh: 晉旱，來請粟。

translations.text: Jin had a drought and came to request grain.

sentences.zh: 丕豹說繆公勿與，因其饑而伐之。

translations.text: Pi Bao urged Duke Mu not to give it, but to attack them while they were starving.

sentences.zh: 繆公問公孫支，支曰：「饑穰更事耳，不可不與。

translations.text: Duke Mu asked Gongsun Zhi, who said: 'Famine and plenty alternate; we cannot refuse.'

sentences.zh: 」問百里傒，傒曰：「夷吾得罪於君，其百姓何罪？

translations.text: He asked Baili Xi, who said: 'Yiwu offended you, but what crime did his people commit?'

sentences.zh: 」於是用百里傒、公孫支言，卒與之粟。

translations.text: So following the advice of Baili Xi and Gongsun Zhi, he gave them grain.

sentences.zh: 以船漕車轉，自雍相望至絳。

translations.text: By boat and cart transport, an unbroken line stretched from Yong to Jiang.

Jin had a drought and came to request grain. Pi Bao urged Duke Mu not to give it, but to attack them while they were starving. Duke Mu asked Gongsun Zhi, who said: 'Famine and plenty alternate; we cannot refuse.' He asked Baili Xi, who said: 'Yiwu offended you, but what crime did his people commit?' So following the advice of Baili Xi and Gongsun Zhi, he gave them grain. By boat and cart transport, an unbroken line stretched from Yong to Jiang.

sentences.zh: 十四年，秦饑，請粟於晉。

translations.text: In the fourteenth year, Qin had a famine and requested grain from Jin.

sentences.zh: 晉君謀之群臣。

translations.text: The ruler of Jin consulted his ministers.

sentences.zh: 虢射曰：「因其饑伐之，可有大功。

translations.text: Guo She said: 'Attack them while they are starving, and you can achieve great merit.'

sentences.zh: 」晉君從之。

translations.text: The ruler of Jin followed this advice.

sentences.zh: 十五年，興兵將攻秦。

translations.text: In the fifteenth year, he raised troops to attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 繆公發兵，使丕豹將，自往擊之。

translations.text: Duke Mu mobilized his forces, sent Pi Bao as general, and went himself to attack them.

sentences.zh: 九月壬戌，與晉惠公夷吾合戰於韓地。

translations.text: On the renxu day of the ninth month, he joined battle with Duke Hui of Jin, Yiwu, at Han.

sentences.zh: 晉君棄其軍，與秦爭利，還而馬騺。

translations.text: The ruler of Jin abandoned his army and competed with Qin for advantage; as he turned back, his horse stumbled.

sentences.zh: 繆公與麾下馳追之，不能得晉君，反為晉軍所圍。

translations.text: Duke Mu and his bodyguards rode in pursuit, but could not catch the ruler of Jin, and were instead surrounded by the Jin army.

sentences.zh: 晉擊繆公，繆公傷。

translations.text: Jin attacked Duke Mu, and Duke Mu was wounded.

sentences.zh: 於是岐下食善馬者三百人馳冒晉軍，晉軍解圍，遂脫繆公而反生得晉君。

translations.text: At that moment, three hundred men from below Mount Qi who had eaten his good horses charged through the Jin army. The Jin army broke their encirclement, and they rescued Duke Mu and in turn captured the ruler of Jin alive.

sentences.zh: 初，繆公亡善馬，岐下野人共得而食之者三百餘人，吏逐得，欲法之。

translations.text: Earlier, Duke Mu had lost some fine horses, and more than three hundred commoners below Mount Qi had caught and eaten them together. Officials tracked them down and wanted to punish them according to law.

sentences.zh: 繆公曰：「君子不以畜產害人。

translations.text: Duke Mu said: 'A gentleman does not harm people for the sake of livestock.

sentences.zh: 吾聞食善馬肉不飲酒，傷人。

translations.text: I have heard that eating good horse meat without drinking wine harms a person.'

sentences.zh: 」乃皆賜酒而赦之。

translations.text: So he gave them all wine and pardoned them.

sentences.zh: 三百人者聞秦擊晉，皆求從，從而見繆公窘，亦皆推鋒爭死，以報食馬之德。

translations.text: When the three hundred men heard that Qin was attacking Jin, they all sought to join the campaign. When they saw Duke Mu in distress, they all charged forward and vied to die for him, to repay his kindness in the matter of the horses.

sentences.zh: 於是繆公虜晉君以歸，令於國，齊宿，吾將以晉君祠上帝。

translations.text: Duke Mu then brought the captured ruler of Jin home and issued an order throughout the state that they should purify themselves, for he would sacrifice the ruler of Jin to the Supreme Deity.

sentences.zh: 周天子聞之，曰「晉我同姓」，為請晉君。

translations.text: When the Zhou Son of Heaven heard this, he said, 'Jin is of the same surname as us,' and requested the release of the ruler of Jin.

sentences.zh: 夷吾姊亦為繆公夫人，夫人聞之，乃衰绖跣，曰：「妾兄弟不能相救，以辱君命。

translations.text: Yiwu's elder sister was also Duke Mu's wife. When she heard this, she put on mourning clothes, went barefoot, and said: 'My brother and I cannot save each other, and thus we have disgraced your command.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公曰：「我得晉君以為功，今天子為請，夫人是憂。

translations.text: Duke Mu said: 'I captured the ruler of Jin as an achievement, but now the Son of Heaven requests his release, and my wife is distressed.'

sentences.zh: 」乃與晉君盟，許歸之，更舍上舍，而饋之七牢。

translations.text: So he made a covenant with the ruler of Jin, agreed to return him, moved him to better quarters, and presented him with seven sets of sacrificial animals.

sentences.zh: 十一月，歸晉君夷吾，夷吾獻其河西地，使太子圉為質於秦。

translations.text: In the eleventh month, he returned the ruler of Jin, Yiwu. Yiwu ceded his lands west of the river and sent his heir apparent Yu as a hostage to Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦妻子圉以宗女。

translations.text: Qin gave a woman of the royal clan in marriage to Yu.

sentences.zh: 是時秦地東至河。

translations.text: At this time, Qin's territory extended east to the Yellow River.

In the fourteenth year, Qin had a famine and requested grain from Jin. The ruler of Jin consulted his ministers. Guo She said: 'Attack them while they are starving, and you can achieve great merit.' The ruler of Jin followed this advice. In the fifteenth year, he raised troops to attack Qin. Duke Mu mobilized his forces, sent Pi Bao as general, and went himself to attack them. On the renxu day of the ninth month, he joined battle with Duke Hui of Jin, Yiwu, at Han. The ruler of Jin abandoned his army and competed with Qin for advantage; as he turned back, his horse stumbled. Duke Mu and his bodyguards rode in pursuit, but could not catch the ruler of Jin, and were instead surrounded by the Jin army. Jin attacked Duke Mu, and Duke Mu was wounded. At that moment, three hundred men from below Mount Qi who had eaten his good horses charged through the Jin army. The Jin army broke their encirclement, and they rescued Duke Mu and in turn captured the ruler of Jin alive. Earlier, Duke Mu had lost some fine horses, and more than three hundred commoners below Mount Qi had caught and eaten them together. Officials tracked them down and wanted to punish them according to law. Duke Mu said: 'A gentleman does not harm people for the sake of livestock. I have heard that eating good horse meat without drinking wine harms a person.' So he gave them all wine and pardoned them. When the three hundred men heard that Qin was attacking Jin, they all sought to join the campaign. When they saw Duke Mu in distress, they all charged forward and vied to die for him, to repay his kindness in the matter of the horses. Duke Mu then brought the captured ruler of Jin home and issued an order throughout the state that they should purify themselves, for he would sacrifice the ruler of Jin to the Supreme Deity. When the Zhou Son of Heaven heard this, he said, 'Jin is of the same surname as us,' and requested the release of the ruler of Jin. Yiwu's elder sister was also Duke Mu's wife. When she heard this, she put on mourning clothes, went barefoot, and said: 'My brother and I cannot save each other, and thus we have disgraced your command.' Duke Mu said: 'I captured the ruler of Jin as an achievement, but now the Son of Heaven requests his release, and my wife is distressed.' So he made a covenant with the ruler of Jin, agreed to return him, moved him to better quarters, and presented him with seven sets of sacrificial animals. In the eleventh month, he returned the ruler of Jin, Yiwu. Yiwu ceded his lands west of the river and sent his heir apparent Yu as a hostage to Qin. Qin gave a woman of the royal clan in marriage to Yu. At this time, Qin's territory extended east to the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 十八年，齊桓公卒。

translations.text: In the eighteenth year, Duke Huan of Qi died.

sentences.zh: 二十年，秦滅梁、芮。

translations.text: In the twentieth year, Qin destroyed Liang and Rui.
In the eighteenth year, Duke Huan of Qi died. In the twentieth year, Qin destroyed Liang and Rui.

sentences.zh: 二十二年，晉公子圉聞晉君病，曰：「梁，我母家也，而秦滅之。

translations.text: In the twenty-second year, Prince Yu of Jin heard that the ruler of Jin was ill, and said: 'Liang is my mother's home, and Qin has destroyed it.

sentences.zh: 我兄弟多，即君百歲後，秦必留我，而晉輕，亦更立他子。

translations.text: I have many brothers. When the ruler passes, Qin will certainly detain me, and Jin will regard me lightly and establish another son.'

sentences.zh: 」子圉乃亡歸晉。

translations.text: So Yu fled and returned to Jin.

sentences.zh: 二十三年，晉惠公卒，子圉立為君。

translations.text: In the twenty-third year, Duke Hui of Jin died, and Yu was established as ruler.

sentences.zh: 秦怨圉亡去，乃迎晉公子重耳於楚，而妻以故子圉妻。

translations.text: Qin resented Yu for fleeing, so they welcomed Prince Chong'er of Jin from Chu and gave him Yu's former wife in marriage.

sentences.zh: 重耳初謝，後乃受。

translations.text: Chong'er at first declined, but later accepted.

sentences.zh: 繆公益禮厚遇之。

translations.text: Duke Mu treated him with ever greater courtesy and generosity.

sentences.zh: 二十四年春，秦使人告晉大臣，欲入重耳。

translations.text: In the spring of the twenty-fourth year, Qin sent someone to tell the ministers of Jin that they wished to install Chong'er.

sentences.zh: 晉許之，於是使人送重耳。

translations.text: Jin agreed, and so they sent someone to escort Chong'er.

sentences.zh: 二月，重耳立為晉君，是為文公。

translations.text: In the second month, Chong'er was established as ruler of Jin; this was Duke Wen.

sentences.zh: 文公使人殺子圉。

translations.text: Duke Wen had someone kill Yu.

sentences.zh: 子圉是為懷公。

translations.text: Yu was known as Duke Huai.

In the twenty-second year, Prince Yu of Jin heard that the ruler of Jin was ill, and said: 'Liang is my mother's home, and Qin has destroyed it. I have many brothers. When the ruler passes, Qin will certainly detain me, and Jin will regard me lightly and establish another son.' So Yu fled and returned to Jin. In the twenty-third year, Duke Hui of Jin died, and Yu was established as ruler. Qin resented Yu for fleeing, so they welcomed Prince Chong'er of Jin from Chu and gave him Yu's former wife in marriage. Chong'er at first declined, but later accepted. Duke Mu treated him with ever greater courtesy and generosity. In the spring of the twenty-fourth year, Qin sent someone to tell the ministers of Jin that they wished to install Chong'er. Jin agreed, and so they sent someone to escort Chong'er. In the second month, Chong'er was established as ruler of Jin; this was Duke Wen. Duke Wen had someone kill Yu. Yu was known as Duke Huai.

sentences.zh: 其秋，周襄王弟帶以翟伐王，王出居鄭。

translations.text: That autumn, King Xiang of Zhou's younger brother Dai attacked the king with the Di, and the king went to live in Zheng.

sentences.zh: 二十五年，周王使人告難於晉、秦。

translations.text: In the twenty-fifth year, the Zhou king sent someone to report the troubles to Jin and Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦繆公將兵助晉文公入襄王，殺王弟帶。

translations.text: Duke Mu of Qin led troops to help Duke Wen of Jin restore King Xiang and killed the king's brother Dai.

sentences.zh: 二十八年，晉文公敗楚於城濮。

translations.text: In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Wen of Jin defeated Chu at Chengpu.

sentences.zh: 三十年，繆公助晉文公圍鄭。

translations.text: In the thirtieth year, Duke Mu assisted Duke Wen of Jin in besieging Zheng.

sentences.zh: 鄭使人言繆公曰：「亡鄭厚晉，於晉而得矣，而秦未有利。

translations.text: Zheng sent someone to say to Duke Mu: 'Destroying Zheng will benefit Jin; Jin will gain from it, but Qin will have no benefit.

sentences.zh: 晉之彊，秦之憂也。

translations.text: Jin's strength is Qin's worry.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公乃罷兵歸。

translations.text: Duke Mu then withdrew his troops and returned.

sentences.zh: 晉亦罷。

translations.text: Jin also withdrew.

sentences.zh: 三十二年冬，晉文公卒。

translations.text: In the winter of the thirty-second year, Duke Wen of Jin died.

That autumn, King Xiang of Zhou's younger brother Dai attacked the king with the Di, and the king went to live in Zheng. In the twenty-fifth year, the Zhou king sent someone to report the troubles to Jin and Qin. Duke Mu of Qin led troops to help Duke Wen of Jin restore King Xiang and killed the king's brother Dai. In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Wen of Jin defeated Chu at Chengpu. In the thirtieth year, Duke Mu assisted Duke Wen of Jin in besieging Zheng. Zheng sent someone to say to Duke Mu: 'Destroying Zheng will benefit Jin; Jin will gain from it, but Qin will have no benefit. Jin's strength is Qin's worry.' Duke Mu then withdrew his troops and returned. Jin also withdrew. In the winter of the thirty-second year, Duke Wen of Jin died.

sentences.zh: 鄭人有賣鄭於秦曰：「我主其城門，鄭可襲也。

translations.text: A man from Zheng came to sell out Zheng to Qin, saying: 'I am in charge of the city gates; Zheng can be taken by surprise.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公問蹇叔、百里傒，對曰：「徑數國千里而襲人，希有得利者。

translations.text: Duke Mu asked Jian Shu and Baili Xi, who replied: 'To travel a thousand li through several states to attack someone by surprise rarely succeeds.

sentences.zh: 且人賣鄭，庸知我國人不有以我情告鄭者乎？

translations.text: Moreover, if someone is selling out Zheng, how do we know that someone from our own state will not inform Zheng of our plans?

sentences.zh: 不可。

translations.text: This cannot be done.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公曰：「子不知也，吾已決矣。

translations.text: Duke Mu said: 'You do not understand; I have already decided.'

sentences.zh: 」遂發兵，使百里傒子孟明視，蹇叔子西乞術及白乙丙將兵。

translations.text: So he dispatched troops, sending Baili Xi's son Mengming Shi, Jian Shu's son Xi Qishu, and Bai Yibing to lead the army.

sentences.zh: 行日，百里傒、蹇叔二人哭之。

translations.text: On the day they departed, Baili Xi and Jian Shu wept for them.

sentences.zh: 繆公聞，怒曰：「孤發兵而子沮哭吾軍，何也？

translations.text: Duke Mu heard of this and angrily said: 'I dispatch troops and you weep to demoralize my army; why?'

sentences.zh: 」二老曰：「臣非敢沮君軍。

translations.text: The two elders said: 'We would not dare to demoralize your army.

sentences.zh: 軍行，臣子與往；

translations.text: The army marches, and our sons go with it;

sentences.zh: 臣老，遲還恐不相見，故哭耳。

translations.text: we are old, and fear we will not live to see their return, so we weep.'

sentences.zh: 」二老退，謂其子曰：「汝軍即敗，必於殽阨矣。

translations.text: The two elders withdrew and said to their sons: 'When your army is defeated, it will certainly be at the Xiao Pass.'

sentences.zh: 」三十三年春，秦兵遂東，更晉地，過周北門。

translations.text: In the spring of the thirty-third year, the Qin army marched east, crossed Jin territory, and passed by the north gate of Zhou.

sentences.zh: 周王孫滿曰：「秦師無禮，不敗何待！

translations.text: Prince Man of Zhou said: 'The Qin army is disrespectful; what else can they expect but defeat!'

sentences.zh: 」兵至滑，鄭販賣賈人弦高，持十二牛將賣之周，見秦兵，恐死虜，因獻其牛，曰：「聞大國將誅鄭，鄭君謹修守御備，使臣以牛十二勞軍士。

translations.text: When the army reached Hua, a Zheng merchant named Xian Gao, who was taking twelve oxen to sell in Zhou, saw the Qin army. Fearing he would be killed or captured, he presented his oxen, saying: 'I have heard that a great power is coming to punish Zheng. The ruler of Zheng is carefully preparing his defenses, and has sent me with twelve oxen to reward the soldiers.'

sentences.zh: 」秦三將軍相謂曰：「將襲鄭，鄭今已覺之，往無及已。

translations.text: The three Qin generals said to each other: 'We were going to surprise Zheng, but now Zheng is aware of it; there is no point in going.'

sentences.zh: 」滅滑。

translations.text: They destroyed Hua.

sentences.zh: 滑，晉之邊邑也。

translations.text: Hua was a border town of Jin.

A man from Zheng came to sell out Zheng to Qin, saying: 'I am in charge of the city gates; Zheng can be taken by surprise.' Duke Mu asked Jian Shu and Baili Xi, who replied: 'To travel a thousand li through several states to attack someone by surprise rarely succeeds. Moreover, if someone is selling out Zheng, how do we know that someone from our own state will not inform Zheng of our plans? This cannot be done.' Duke Mu said: 'You do not understand; I have already decided.' So he dispatched troops, sending Baili Xi's son Mengming Shi, Jian Shu's son Xi Qishu, and Bai Yibing to lead the army. On the day they departed, Baili Xi and Jian Shu wept for them. Duke Mu heard of this and angrily said: 'I dispatch troops and you weep to demoralize my army; why?' The two elders said: 'We would not dare to demoralize your army. The army marches, and our sons go with it; we are old, and fear we will not live to see their return, so we weep.' The two elders withdrew and said to their sons: 'When your army is defeated, it will certainly be at the Xiao Pass.' In the spring of the thirty-third year, the Qin army marched east, crossed Jin territory, and passed by the north gate of Zhou. Prince Man of Zhou said: 'The Qin army is disrespectful; what else can they expect but defeat!' When the army reached Hua, a Zheng merchant named Xian Gao, who was taking twelve oxen to sell in Zhou, saw the Qin army. Fearing he would be killed or captured, he presented his oxen, saying: 'I have heard that a great power is coming to punish Zheng. The ruler of Zheng is carefully preparing his defenses, and has sent me with twelve oxen to reward the soldiers.' The three Qin generals said to each other: 'We were going to surprise Zheng, but now Zheng is aware of it; there is no point in going.' They destroyed Hua. Hua was a border town of Jin.

sentences.zh: 當是時，晉文公喪尚未葬。

translations.text: At that time, Duke Wen of Jin's coffin had not yet been buried.

sentences.zh: 太子襄公怒曰：「秦侮我孤，因喪破我滑。

translations.text: The heir apparent Duke Xiang angrily said: 'Qin has insulted me as an orphan, taking advantage of the mourning period to destroy our Hua.'

sentences.zh: 」遂墨衰绖，發兵遮秦兵於殽，擊之，大破秦軍，無一人得脫者。

translations.text: So he dyed his mourning clothes black, dispatched troops to intercept the Qin army at Xiao, and attacked them, completely destroying the Qin army. Not one man escaped.

sentences.zh: 虜秦三將以歸。

translations.text: He captured the three Qin generals and brought them back.

sentences.zh: 文公夫人，秦女也，為秦三囚將請曰：「繆公之怨此三人入於骨髓，願令此三人歸，令我君得自快烹之。

translations.text: Duke Wen's wife was a Qin woman. On behalf of the three imprisoned Qin generals, she requested: 'Duke Mu's hatred of these three men has entered his very bones and marrow. I beg you to let these three men return, so that my lord may have the pleasure of boiling them himself.'

sentences.zh: 」晉君許之，歸秦三將。

translations.text: The ruler of Jin agreed and returned the three Qin generals.

sentences.zh: 三將至，繆公素服郊迎，向三人哭曰：「孤以不用百里傒、蹇叔言以辱三子，三子何罪乎？

translations.text: When the three generals arrived, Duke Mu put on plain clothes, went out to the suburbs to meet them, and wept to the three men, saying: 'Because I did not follow the advice of Baili Xi and Jian Shu, I brought disgrace upon you three. What was your crime?

sentences.zh: 子其悉心雪恥，毋怠。

translations.text: You must devote yourselves wholeheartedly to washing away this shame; do not be negligent.'

sentences.zh: 」遂復三人官秩如故，愈益厚之。

translations.text: He then restored the three men to their former ranks and offices, and treated them even more generously.

At that time, Duke Wen of Jin's coffin had not yet been buried. The heir apparent Duke Xiang angrily said: 'Qin has insulted me as an orphan, taking advantage of the mourning period to destroy our Hua.' So he dyed his mourning clothes black, dispatched troops to intercept the Qin army at Xiao, and attacked them, completely destroying the Qin army. Not one man escaped. He captured the three Qin generals and brought them back. Duke Wen's wife was a Qin woman. On behalf of the three imprisoned Qin generals, she requested: 'Duke Mu's hatred of these three men has entered his very bones and marrow. I beg you to let these three men return, so that my lord may have the pleasure of boiling them himself.' The ruler of Jin agreed and returned the three Qin generals. When the three generals arrived, Duke Mu put on plain clothes, went out to the suburbs to meet them, and wept to the three men, saying: 'Because I did not follow the advice of Baili Xi and Jian Shu, I brought disgrace upon you three. What was your crime? You must devote yourselves wholeheartedly to washing away this shame; do not be negligent.' He then restored the three men to their former ranks and offices, and treated them even more generously.

sentences.zh: 三十四年，楚太子商臣弒其父成王代立。

translations.text: In the thirty-fourth year, Prince Shangchen of Chu assassinated his father King Cheng and took his place.
In the thirty-fourth year, Prince Shangchen of Chu assassinated his father King Cheng and took his place.

sentences.zh: 繆公於是復使孟明視等將兵伐晉，戰于彭衙。

translations.text: Duke Mu then again sent Mengming Shi and the others to lead troops against Jin, and they fought at Pengya.

sentences.zh: 秦不利，引兵歸。

translations.text: Qin did not prevail and withdrew its troops.
Duke Mu then again sent Mengming Shi and the others to lead troops against Jin, and they fought at Pengya. Qin did not prevail and withdrew its troops.

sentences.zh: 戎王使由余於秦。

translations.text: The king of the Rong sent You Yu to Qin.

sentences.zh: 由余，其先晉人也，亡入戎，能晉言。

translations.text: You Yu's ancestors were people of Jin who had fled to the Rong, and he could speak the Jin language.

sentences.zh: 聞繆公賢，故使由余觀秦。

translations.text: Hearing that Duke Mu was worthy, he sent You Yu to observe Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦繆公示以宮室、積聚。

translations.text: Duke Mu of Qin showed him the palaces and storehouses.

sentences.zh: 由余曰：「使鬼為之，則勞神矣。

translations.text: You Yu said: 'If spirits made these, then the spirits have been wearied.

sentences.zh: 使人為之，亦苦民矣。

translations.text: If men made these, then the people have been oppressed.'

sentences.zh: 」繆公怪之，問曰：「中國以詩書禮樂法度為政，然尚時亂，今戎夷無此，何以為治，不亦難乎？

translations.text: Duke Mu was surprised and asked: 'The Central States use the Odes, Documents, rites, music, and laws to govern, yet they still have disorder from time to time. Now the Rong and Yi have none of these; how do they govern? Is it not difficult?'

sentences.zh: 」由余笑曰：「此乃中國所以亂也。

translations.text: You Yu laughed and said: 'This is precisely why the Central States are in disorder.

sentences.zh: 夫自上聖黃帝作為禮樂法度，身以先之，僅以小治。

translations.text: From the time when the sage Huangdi created rites, music, and laws, and practiced them himself, there was barely minor order.

sentences.zh: 及其後世，日以驕淫。

translations.text: By subsequent generations, they became daily more arrogant and dissolute.

sentences.zh: 阻法度之威，以責督於下，下罷極則以仁義怨望於上，上下交爭怨而相篡弒，至於滅宗，皆以此類也。

translations.text: They relied on the authority of laws to demand service from their subordinates. When the subordinates were exhausted, they resented the superiors on grounds of humanity and righteousness. Superiors and subordinates fought and resented each other, leading to usurpation and regicide until whole clans were exterminated. All such cases belong to this pattern.

sentences.zh: 夫戎夷不然。

translations.text: The Rong and Yi are not like this.

sentences.zh: 上含淳德以遇其下，下懷忠信以事其上，一國之政猶一身之治，不知所以治，此真聖人之治也。

sentences.zh: 」繆公曰：「善。
